TEXT.S: Los Angeles Times Page 1 for Thursday, March 3, 2005:

Col 1: Both the U.S. Supreme Court and the California Supreme Court are considering the question of how far prosecutors should be allowed to go in presenting conflicting facts to different juries. (COURT-PROSECUTE, moved.)

Cols 2-5: The Supreme Court struggles with the politically charged issue of whether prominent display of the Ten Commandments at government buildings violates separation of church and state. (with art) (SCOTUS-TIMES, moved.)
Col 6: California state finance story moving about 12:30 a.m. EST.
Cols 2-4: Story on Los Angeles Mayor James Hahn's record on crime.

Col 1: Kobe Bryant and the woman who accused him of rape settle her civil lawsuit out of court, marking the end of an often graphic 20-month legal saga that drew worldwide attention but never resulted in a trial. (BRYANT, upcoming about midnight EST.)

Col 4: In an effort to clear up what he says are misunderstandings, a North Korean "businessman" expounds in a rare interview on the North Korean view of the world in an informal conversation. 1,170 words, by Barbara Demick (Times). (NKOREA-OFFICIAL, moved.)

Cols 5-6: A leading Italian prosecutor opens an investigation into the February 2003 disappearance of Hassan Osama Nasr in Milan, which has the hallmarks of a so-called "extraordinary rendition," a tactic in which American counter-terrorism agents seize and transport suspects to third countries without seeking court permission. (ITALY-VANISHED, moved.)
